conclusion: To determine if the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The x-axis represents time (t) in seconds. The y-axis represents velocity (v) in meters per second (m/s).
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases further from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
Variable linear motion implies that the velocity is changing over time.
In the first second (0 to 1 s), the velocity is constant, so there is no change.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases, indicating a change.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity continues to decrease, indicating another change.
Since the velocity changes during the intervals from 1 to 2 seconds and from 2 to 3 seconds, the particle undergoes variable linear motion during these periods.
However, from 0 to 1 second, the motion is not variable as the velocity is constant.
Yes, the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, specifically from 1 to 3 seconds.
